summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, discussing technical discovery issues related to electronic evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices. The emails focus on metadata, file formats, access to discovery materials for Maxwell in prison, and the handling of over 100,000 files including emails, photographs, and videos.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with prosecutors about discovery issues, requesting metadata and file access.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, involved in discovery discussions regarding file formats and metadata.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, corresponding with defense about discovery production and technical issues.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on discovery-related email correspondence.

persons.name: Tom Powers
persons.context: Colleague of Christian Everdell, requested to be included on the response regarding USAfx account setup.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case, referenced as being unable to review discovery files at the MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the source of electronic devices and files seized during searches of his residences, which are the subject of the discovery production.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case, mentioned as a potential authority to resolve disputes over discovery delivery to the MDC.

connections.description: Co-defense attorneys representing Ghislaine Maxwell, collaborating on discovery issues.
Defense attorney and prosecutor corresponding about discovery production and technical issues in the Maxwell case.
Maxwell is the defendant in a case involving evidence seized from Epstein's devices, indicating their prior association.
Colleagues at the same law firm (implied), with Everdell requesting Powers be included on correspondence.
Co-defense attorneys for Ghislaine Maxwell, both copied on discovery correspondence.

events.title: Searches of Epstein Residences
events.description: The FBI conducted searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residences, seizing CDs containing images and other electronic evidence.

events.title: November 9, 2020 Discovery Production
events.description: Prosecution produced discovery to the defense, including images from CDs seized from Epstein's residences.

events.title: Discovery Issues Raised
events.description: Defense attorneys sent a detailed list of discovery issues to prosecutors, including missing attachments, metadata problems, and access for Maxwell.

events.title: USAfx Account Setup Request
events.description: Defense requests setup of a USAfx account to receive new discovery production electronically.

keyFacts: Over 109,000 emails were produced without their attachments, with attachments appearing only as slip-sheets.
Over 110,000 electronic documents from Epstein's devices have metadata showing 'date created' or 'date last modified' dates in July 2020 or later, raising questions about file integrity.
Over 6,500 photographs were produced in native format but lack CART numbers and have post-July 2019 dates, with the defense requesting original metadata.
Ghislaine Maxwell was unable to review certain discovery files at the MDC due to technical limitations with prison computers reading disks.
Evidence includes images from CDs seized during 2019 searches of Epstein's residences, which were not processed by CART and thus lack certain tracking numbers.
